p: In recent years, climate change has been established as a clear and emerging global process, and adverse impacts on biological elements have been reported worldwide ( Bellard et al., 2012). Climate change effects have been documented for both human populations and biodiversity ( Chang et al., 2015); examples of the latter include pest and disease outbreaks ( Woods, Coates & Hamann, 2005), temporal reproductive isolation ( Lowry & Willis, 2010), and changes in speciesâ€™ distribution and phenology ( Peterson et al., 2004). The situation is expected to become more dramatic as the pace and magnitude of environmental changes quicken ( Meehl et al., 2007), and may prove to be more adverse in developing countries as compared to developed countries ( IPCC, 2014).
